repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Agricultural Rehabilitation
            and Development Project (ARDP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project achieved mixed outcomes. It
            was successful in establishing extension networks for
            restoring Government agricultural services, and
            contributions were made to sector and sub-sector planning,
            namely, on reform analysis for cashew processing and
            marketing. Nevertheless, poor project design, and, limited
            and delayed implementation, coupled with failed production
            objectives, hindered success. Furthermore, minimal progress
            was achieved in reversing development constraints for both,
            producers and processors. The key lessons convey that
            projects should provide a platform to support policy
            reforms, particularly in countries where macroeconomic and
            agricultural policies are not in place. Project success
            cannot be guaranteed without effective implementation of
            policy frameworks, which would prod disbursement of project
            funds. Consideration to technical assistance, training and
            research, require priority design, to restore production
            constraints in the agricultural sub-sector, and, be in tune
            with the overall institutional capacity. Hence, fundamental
            actions/activities for project development, need to be
            incorporated in project design to ensure accountability, and
            be responsive to the prevailing context. Timely provision of
            counterpart funds is essential, particularly for
            agricultural operations; thus projects require an
            appropriate scale, and a proactive management to achieve sustainability.

18151313.theme: Other financial and private sector development,Administrative and civil service reform

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Agricultural Rehabilitation
            and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to : (a)
            reverse the decline in production and marketing of cashew
            nuts and restore exports to their levels of the seventies;
            (b) make small- and medium-scale agricultural enterprises
            more efficient and profitable; and (c) strengthen local
            capacity to formulate and implement long-term growth
            strategies for the irrigation and cashew subsectors.  The
            project components include: (a) rehabilitation and
            development of the cashew subsector; (b) assistance to
            agricultural enterprises; and (c) specific subsectoral
            studies and surveys.  Under the first component, financing
            will be provided for: (a) equipment, incremental costs and
            technical assistance to agricultural extension, research,
            and cashew nut nurseries and to the state secretariat; (b)
            investment credit to commercial farmers and traders and for
            cashew processing factories.  Because women play a dominant
            role in agriculture and cashew marketing, a survey will be
            carried out to assess factors determining the agricultural
            productivity of women and measures to be taken to enhance
            benefits accruing to them.  Under the second component,
            financing for technical assistance, incremental costs, and
            equipment will be provided to develop a capacity within the
            Ministry of Agriculture to address the rehabilitation needs
            of agricultural enterprises and provide them with managerial
            and planning assistance and training.  The third component
            will finance studies and surveys.
